div.p: An attribute of TITLE (mandatory), TITLETYPE indicates whether a title is a part of another work, an entire work, a journal, or a series. Use it throughout the textbase. It has the following values: analytic (article, poem, or other item published as part of a larger item); monographic (book or collection, including both single volumes in a multi-volume work or the whole set of volumes); journal (including magazines and newspapers, the entire publication; pieces in journal are analytic); series; unpublished, including manuscripts and conference papers. (Dissertations have generally been classed as monographic.)

div.codeblock: <TITLE TITLETYPE="monographic">Timetables of History</TITLE> <TITLE TITLETYPE="monographic">Encyclopedia Britannica</TITLE> <TITLE TITLETYPE="journal">Illustrated London News</TITLE> <TITLE TITLETYPE="journal">New York Tribune</TITLE>

div.p: Every title that is tagged must be labelled with the TITLETYPE attribute for two purposes: searching and display. (A title with no attribute value will not be fitted with italics or quotes.)
Question: What exactly is a series?

Answer: A group of independent monographs linked together by a shared series title. That is, the publisher has supplied a collective title apart from the individual title of each item. The individual items may or may not be numbered. Examples are Virago Modern Classics, Mothers of the Novel (published by Pandora), Olympia Press Traveller's Companion Series, Contemporary Authors, The Dictionary of Literary Biography, British Children's Writers, 1800-1880. If you are not sure whether or not something is a series title, check its full record in a library catalogue.
